item.title: Paint System
item.dc:creator: @sh_ft sh!ft
item.description:
@sh_ft wrote:

[quote=“speedster239, post:11, topic:163812”]Ok guys, I’ve worked out this problem. For future reference I put the draw function in it’s own thread as follows:

Thread paintThread = new Thread() { public void run() {
		while(loop == true){
		draw("("+getTileX()+","+getTileY()+")",15,35);
		}
		} };
		paintThread.start();

Thanks everyone
This allows me to run the rest of the processes without eating up to much memory. I tried running two draw’s on the same thread but I ran into a “flicker” problem so I just put them on seperate threads.[/quote]

The flickering occurs due to desynchronization. You need to inject some how in the draw screen, like I said.

BTW AT LEAST put a Thread.sleep(long) in the loop, otherwise it’ll tear through your processor, not your memory mate And, notice that on dual cores, the most it will eat is 50%.

item.dc:creator: @sh_ft sh!ft
item.description:
@sh_ft wrote:

[quote=“speedster239, post:1, topic:163812”]Ok, I’ve got a working paint system in Jmacro now, seen below. I have one problem, when I draw a string it only appears for a split second. Does anybody have any ideas on how I can make it appear for longer without stopping all of the other processes (ie putting it in a while loop).

If you want to see any source code etc etc I’ll post it but since most canvashacks are done the same way so I don’t know if it’s necessary.

Speeedster239…[/quote]
The issue is speedster, is that the game prints 50 frames per second. Thus drawing to hte game screen will only stay for 20 ms. To work around this you actually have to hook the canvas class, and override the “Graphics getGraphics()” method, and send it a graphics field of our own BufferedImage, at least this is how I would approach such a thing.

It works flawlessly for me, of course, you can also just add a canvas to the canvas on top of it… :-p and set it to let the super canvas draw first.
